subject: Gardening
title: Mycorrhizal Fungi Networks
description: A short lesson to help you apply Mycorrhizal Fungi Networks.

hook.text: Trees in forests share nutrients through underground fungal networks. Scientists call it the 'Wood Wide Web.'

buildup.text: Mycorrhizal fungi attach to plant roots and extend thread-like hyphae through soil, massively increasing root reach.

discovery.text: Plants connected by mycorrhizae can transfer carbon, nitrogen, and phosphorus to each otherâ€”even between species.

twist.text: Mother trees send more resources to their offspring through the network. The system isn't equalâ€”it shows plant 'kinship.

climax.text: Gardens that maintain mycorrhizal networks through no-dig methods have plants that communicate and share resources.

punchline.text: Your garden has an internet. It runs on fungi.

quiz.question: What surprising behavior do mother trees show through mycorrhizal networks?
options: They poison competing trees' connections to the network
They send more resources to their own offspring than to unrelated trees
They only connect to trees of the same species and age
